<p> Using this week's #tidytuesday Dataset gotten from Steam, I created a Shiny Web Application that shows p-values and estimates for selected games. Link can be found <a href = ""> here </a> </p>
<p> I also delved into Data Art. I found it abit challenging to come up with an actual design, after a lot of trials, i came up with this.

```{r echo=TRUE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8}
library(tidyverse)
## loading data
movies_df <- read_csv("games.txt")

 movies_df %>%
  ## Some data cleaning
  mutate(avg_peak_perc = parse_number(avg_peak_perc),
         sign_check = str_starts(gamename, "<")) %>%
  filter(!is.na(gain),!is.na(avg_peak_perc), sign_check == FALSE) %>%
  select(avg:avg_peak_perc) %>%
  cor() %>%
  as.data.frame() %>%
  mutate(vars = c("avg", "gain", "peak", "avg_peak_perc")) %>%
  gather(value = "value", key = "key", -vars) %>%
  ggplot(aes(vars, key, fill = value)) +
  geom_hex() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

```
